questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para calcular un promedio?
questions.example: Our expenses averaged out at $500 per month.
questions.context: Used when calculating the average result of numbers or amounts.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para eliminar algo/alguien?
questions.example: The company plans to do away with paper invoices.
questions.context: Used when abolishing, getting rid of, or removing something or someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para proceder con algo?
questions.example: Despite objections, the manager went ahead with the plan.
questions.context: Used when you proceed with a plan or action.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para admitir algo?
questions.example: He owned up to breaking the window.
questions.context: Used when someone admits responsibility for something wrong.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para sumar un total?
questions.example: The bills add up to $300.
questions.context: Used when amounts combine to make a total.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para privar a alguien de algo?
questions.example: She was done out of her promotion by a colleague.
questions.context: Used when someone is unfairly deprived of something they deserve.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar de acuerdo con algo?
questions.example: I'll go along with your suggestion.
questions.context: Used when you agree or accept an idea, plan, or suggestion.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para continuar presionando con algo?
questions.example: Despite the rain, they pressed on with the marathon.
questions.context: Used when continuing an activity with determination.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para echarse atrás de algo?
questions.example: He backed out of the contract at the last moment.
questions.context: Used when you decide not to do something you had agreed to.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para visitar a alguien sin avisar?
questions.example: We decided to drop in on our neighbors for a quick chat.
questions.context: Used when visiting someone unexpectedly.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para retractarse de algo?
questions.example: He never goes back on his word.
questions.context: Used when someone breaks a promise or agreement.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para continuar rápidamente?
questions.example: Let's push on with our project despite the difficulties.
questions.context: Used when continuing something with energy and focus.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para hablar mucho de algo?
questions.example: He was on about his new car again.
questions.context: Used when someone keeps talking about a subject, often annoyingly.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para abandonar algo?
questions.example: She dropped out of college in her second year.
questions.context: Used when someone leaves a course, school, or activity before finishing.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para empezar a interesarse por algo?
questions.example: He goes in for extreme sports.
questions.context: Used when someone chooses or starts to like a particular activity.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para atribuir algo a otra cosa?
questions.example: She puts her success down to hard work.
questions.context: Used to identify the cause of something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar dispuesto a algo?
questions.example: Are you up for going out tonight?
questions.context: Used when someone is willing or ready for an activity.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para enfrentar algo?
questions.example: It's time to face up to your responsibilities.
questions.context: Used when accepting and dealing with something difficult or unpleasant.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para dejar atrás algo?
questions.example: He grew out of his fear of the dark.
questions.context: Used when someone becomes too mature or too old for something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para solicitar algo?
questions.example: She put in for a pay rise.
questions.context: Used when formally requesting something, usually a job or benefit.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar haciendo algo sospechoso?
questions.example: The kids are very quiet. I wonder what they're up to.
questions.context: Used when someone is doing something, often secretly or suspiciously.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para recurrir a algo en caso de necesidad?
questions.example: If I lose my job, I'll have my savings to fall back on.
questions.context: Used when you use something for help when other things have failed.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para esperar algo mejor?
questions.example: They're holding out for a better offer.
questions.context: Used when waiting for what you want or refusing something until you get it.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para animar a alguien a hacer algo malo?
questions.example: Who put you up to breaking the window?
questions.context: Used when someone encourages another to do something, usually wrong.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para brotar en algo (enfermedad, reacción)?
questions.example: She broke out in a rash after eating strawberries.
questions.context: Used when a skin reaction suddenly appears.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para quedarse atrás en algo?
questions.example: He fell behind with his rent payments.
questions.context: Used when you do not do something as quickly as planned.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para mantenerse alejado de alguien/algo?
questions.example: Keep away from the edge of the cliff.
questions.context: Used to warn or advise someone to avoid something or someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para tolerar a alguien/algo?
questions.example: I can't put up with his behavior anymore.
questions.context: Used when you tolerate something unpleasant or annoying.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para escapar de un lugar o situación?
questions.example: Several prisoners broke out of jail.
questions.context: Used when someone escapes from a place or situation.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para tener una pelea con alguien?
questions.example: She fell out with her best friend over a boy.
questions.context: Used when two people stop being friendly after an argument.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para mantenerse al ritmo de algo/alguien?
questions.example: I can't keep up with all these emails.
questions.context: Used when matching the speed or level of someone or something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para comunicarse con alguien para ofrecer ayuda?
questions.example: The company is reaching out to customers for feedback.
questions.context: Used when trying to communicate or offer help to someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para influenciar negativamente a alguien?
questions.example: His jokes always bring me out in laughter.
questions.context: Used when something causes a reaction, usually on the skin or emotionally.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar harto de algo/alguien?
questions.example: I'm fed up with all this noise.
questions.context: Used when you are extremely annoyed or bored with someone or something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para permitir que alguien sepa algo?
questions.example: She let me in on her secret.
questions.context: Used when sharing a secret or private information.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para huir de alguien/algo?
questions.example: He ran away from home at the age of fifteen.
questions.context: Used when escaping from a place or a difficult situation.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para pedir ayuda a distancia?
questions.example: She called out to her friend for help.
questions.context: Used when you shout or speak loudly to attract someone's attention.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para sustituir a alguien temporalmente?
questions.example: I'm filling in for my colleague while she's on leave.
questions.context: Used when temporarily replacing someone in their job or duty.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar atento a un sonido?
questions.example: Listen out for your name being called.
questions.context: Used when paying special attention to hear a particular sound.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para solicitar algo por correo?
questions.example: I sent away for a free sample.
questions.context: Used when requesting something by post or online.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para acusar a alguien de algo?
questions.example: She called him out on his lies.
questions.context: Used when challenging or criticizing someone openly about something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para arreglarle una cita a alguien?
questions.example: My friend fixed me up with a date for the party.
questions.context: Used when arranging for someone to meet or go out with another person.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar a la altura de algo?
questions.example: The product didn't live up to my expectations.
questions.context: Used when something meets or fails to meet standards or expectations.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para evitar algo?
questions.example: He doesn't shy away from difficult questions.
questions.context: Used when deliberately avoiding something or someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para reponer fuerzas con comida, recursos, etc.?
questions.example: We loaded up on snacks for the road trip.
questions.context: Used when collecting or consuming a large amount of something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para ser el suplente de alguien?
questions.example: He stood in for the manager at the meeting.
questions.context: Used when replacing someone temporarily.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para ponerse al día con algo?
questions.example: I need to catch up on some sleep.
questions.context: Used when doing something you have not had time to do earlier.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para conspirar contra alguien?
questions.example: The students ganged up against the new teacher.
questions.context: Used when a group joins together to oppose or criticize someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para menospreciar a alguien?
questions.example: She looks down on people who don't have a degree.
questions.context: Used when considering someone as less important.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para defender a alguien/algo?
questions.example: It's important to stand up for your rights.
questions.context: Used when defending or supporting someone or something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para ponerse al día con alguien?
questions.example: I hope to catch up with you soon.
questions.context: Used when meeting someone to share the latest news, or when reaching the same level as someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para salirse con la suya?
questions.example: He always gets away with cheating.
questions.context: Used when someone does something bad and is not punished.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para esperar algo con ansias?
questions.example: I'm looking forward to the holidays.
questions.context: Used to express excitement about something that will happen.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para cuidar de alguien/algo?
questions.example: Look out for cars when crossing the street.
questions.context: Used when you watch for something or take care to avoid danger.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para desquitarse con alguien?
questions.example: Don't take your frustration out on me.
questions.context: Used when you treat someone badly because you are upset about something else.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para ponerse en contacto con alguien?
questions.example: I'll get back to you as soon as I can.
questions.context: Used when returning a call, message, or reply to someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para vengarse de alguien?
questions.example: She got back at him for lying.
questions.context: Used when taking revenge on someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para admirar a alguien?
questions.example: He has always looked up to his older brother.
questions.context: Used when respecting or admiring someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para aceptar un reto/invitación?
questions.example: I think I'll take you up on your offer.
questions.context: Used when accepting someone's offer or invitation.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para vigilar a alguien/algo?
questions.example: Watch out for pickpockets in the city.
questions.context: Used when being alert for potential danger or problems.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para imponer restricciones a algo?
questions.example: The government is clamping down on tax evasion.
questions.context: Used when taking strict action to stop illegal or unwanted activity.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para acercarse a alguien?
questions.example: The police closed in on the suspect.
questions.context: Used when moving closer in order to catch or attack.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para aprovecharse de algo?
questions.example: They cashed in on the popularity of healthy snacks.
questions.context: Used when taking advantage of a situation for profit.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para revisar a alguien/algo?
questions.example: My boss likes to check up on our progress.
questions.context: Used when making sure that someone is doing what they should.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para contraer una enfermedad?
questions.example: She came down with the flu.
questions.context: Used when becoming sick with an illness.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para criticar duramente a alguien?
questions.example: The coach came down on the team for their poor performance.
questions.context: Used when punishing or criticizing someone strongly.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para presentar algo (evidencia, idea, etc.)?
questions.example: No witnesses have come forward with information.
questions.context: Used when giving information or help, especially to the authorities.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para enfrentarse a algo?
questions.example: We came up against a serious problem.
questions.context: Used when encountering a difficulty or opposition.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para idear algo o sugerir una idea?
questions.example: She came up with a brilliant idea.
questions.context: Used when producing or suggesting an idea or plan.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para reducir el consumo de algo?
questions.example: You should cut back on sugar.
questions.context: Used when consuming less of something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para reducir algo?
questions.example: I've decided to cut down on smoking.
questions.context: Used when reducing the amount of something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para participar en algo?
questions.example: She wanted to get in on the action.
questions.context: Used when becoming involved in an activity.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para quedarse sin algo?
questions.example: We've run out of milk.
questions.context: Used when all of something has been used and there is none left.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para abastecerse de recursos?
questions.example: We loaded up on snacks for the trip.
questions.context: Used when buying or collecting a large amount of something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para sustituir a alguien temporalmente?
questions.example: Could you fill in for me at the meeting?
questions.context: Used when temporarily doing someone else's job.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para ser suplente de alguien?
questions.example: He stood in for the teacher when she was ill.
questions.context: Used when temporarily taking someone's place.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para incitar a alguien a hacer algo malo?
questions.example: Who put you up to this prank?
questions.context: Used when encouraging someone to do something, especially wrong or foolish.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para pedir ayuda a distancia?
questions.example: She called out to the children to come inside.
questions.context: Used when shouting or speaking loudly to attract attention.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para terminar con algo difícil o desagradable?
questions.example: Let's get the meeting over with.
questions.context: Used when doing something unpleasant so it is finished and you can stop worrying.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para posponer algo?
questions.example: We had to put off our trip until next month.
questions.context: Used when delaying or postponing something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para pasar a algo nuevo?
questions.example: Let's move on to the next topic.
questions.context: Used when changing to a new subject, activity, or stage.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para cambiar de tema o actividad?
questions.example: After a short break, we moved on to the main discussion.
questions.context: Used when progressing from one thing to another.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para estar atento a un peligro?
questions.example: Watch out for icy roads.
questions.context: Used to warn about danger or something that requires attention.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para centrarse en un objetivo?
questions.example: The scientists zeroed in on the cause of the disease.
questions.context: Used when directing all attention to one thing.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para hacer las paces con alguien?
questions.example: He tried to make up to his boss after the argument.
questions.context: Used when trying to become friends with someone again, often to gain a benefit.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para salir de un sitio difícil?
questions.example: He walked away from the accident unharmed.
questions.context: Used when leaving a place, situation, or relationship.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para salir de una relación?
questions.example: He walked out on his family.
questions.context: Used when leaving someone you have a relationship or responsibility with.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para hacer algo finalmente?
questions.example: I never got around to calling her.
questions.context: Used when finally doing something you intended to do for a long time.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para avanzar pese a dificultades?
questions.example: They pressed on with the project despite the setbacks.
questions.context: Used when continuing something determinedly, despite difficulties.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para compensar algo?
questions.example: She worked hard to make up for her mistake.
questions.context: Used when doing something good to balance something bad.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para perder una oportunidad?
questions.example: He missed out on the chance to travel abroad.
questions.context: Used when not getting an opportunity or experience.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para mantener la comunicación con alguien?
questions.example: We keep in touch with our old friends from college.
questions.context: Used when maintaining communication with someone.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para darse cuenta de algo?
questions.example: People are waking up to the importance of healthy eating.
questions.context: Used when becoming aware of a fact or situation.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para comparar algo con un estándar?
questions.example: The new employee doesn't measure up to our expectations.
questions.context: Used when reaching the expected standard.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para retirarse de una negociación?
questions.example: She walked away from the deal at the last minute.
questions.context: Used when leaving a situation, often because you don't accept the terms.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para quedarse sin algo?
questions.example: We've run out of time.
questions.context: Used when there is none of something left.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para solicitar algo formalmente?
questions.example: She put in for a transfer to the New York office.
questions.context: Used when officially requesting something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para defenderse frente a alguien?
questions.example: He stood up to the bully at school.
questions.context: Used when defending yourself against a person or force.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para atribuir algo a una causa?
questions.example: He chalked his failure up to bad luck.
questions.context: Used when explaining the reason for something.

questions.question: ¿Phrasal verb para vivir según los estándares de algo?
questions.example: The film didn't live up to my expectations.
questions.context: Used when matching or failing to match an expected standard.
